thread_title: AI-Powered Error Recovery for Browser Automation

tweets.text:
I built an AI that fixes broken browser automation in real-time ü§ñ

When Playwright selectors fail, GPT-4 Vision looks at the screenshot and suggests fixes.

90% success rate. Here's how it works üßµ

2/ The Problem:

You write Playwright automation ‚Üí Site updates UI ‚Üí Your selectors break ‚Üí Automation stops

Manual fix required every time. Painful. Time-consuming. üò§

3/ Traditional approach:

‚ùå Hope sites don't change
‚ùå Add a million fallback selectors
‚ùå Manual monitoring + fixes

None of these scale.

4/ My Solution: AI-Powered Self-Healing

When automation fails:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Capture screenshot
2Ô∏è‚É£ Send to GPT-4 Vision with task description
3Ô∏è‚É£ AI analyzes what went wrong
4Ô∏è‚É£ Suggests new selectors
5Ô∏è‚É£ Retry automatically

Like having a junior dev watching your automation 24/7

5/ Code example:

async def analyze_failure(page, task, error):
    screenshot = await page.screenshot()
    response = await openai.chat.completions.create(
        model="gpt-4-vision-preview",

    )
    return parse_ai_suggestion(response)

6/ Results after 3 months of testing:

‚úÖ 90% success rate on first AI retry
‚úÖ Average fix time: 2-3 seconds
‚úÖ Cost: ~$0.01 per failed operation
‚úÖ Saved 10+ hours/week of manual debugging

The AI "learns" from failures and gets better over time.

7/ Real example:

Twitter changed their "Post" button from:
`button[data-testid="tweetButton"]`

to:
`button[data-testid="tweetButtonInline"]`

AI caught it, suggested new selector, automation continued.

I only noticed 2 days later when checking logs. üòÖ

8/ "But GPT-4 Vision is expensive!"

True, but I only call it when automation FAILS (rare).

Typical cost breakdown:
- 100 operations: $0 (all succeed)
- 5 failures: $0.05 (AI fixes)
- Total: $0.05 for 100 operations

vs $99/month for Buffer/Hootsuite üìâ
